obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 5 - Russel's Reserve 13 Year - Spring 2025.md
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.title: Review 5 - Russel's Reserve 13 Year - Spring 2025
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.content:
### Initial Thoughts

Every time Russell’s 13 drops, expectations are sky high, and this batch delivers. It brings that classic Wild Turkey funk in spades. The nose pulls you in with funk and rich sweetness, and the first sip confirms it’s dialed in. It’s bold, balanced, and well aged without drifting into heavy oak. I’ve heard and watched (YouTube) people say it’s not as strong as past releases, but I can only judge what’s in my glass, and it’s pretty darn good.
#### Glass: Glencairn - Rested for: 2 hours (went on a walk)

#### Proof: 123.8

#### Age: 13 Years old (youngest component)

#### Mashbill: 75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley

#### Appearance: Red Amber

## Nose
Classic Wild Turkey funk turned up a good notch. Rich caramel and brown sugar open up, backed by toasted walnut and nutmeg. Layers of oak char, cherry, and cinnamon add depth. Subtle hints of leather and tobacco linger underneath.

## Palate
The palate opens with a rush of cherries, followed by layers of caramel and brown sugar. Charred oak steps in next, bringing cinnamon and walnut and nutmeg before easing into a dry finish of leather, dark chocolate and tobacco. The proof feels spot on, balanced and cohesive, letting each note play its part without anything overpowering the rest.
## Finish
The finish is long and steady, carrying forward the oak, leather, and tobacco from the palate. A touch of dark chocolate and dry spice linger as the sweetness fades, leaving a warm, drying finish. Makes me want to sip again!

## Final Thoughts
This release hits a great balance of depth and drinkability. The oak, leather, and tobacco carry through without getting super bitter, and that touch of dark chocolate and spice ties it all together. It’s layered, consistent, and easy to come back to. Definitely one of those pours that keeps you reaching for another glass. Turkey fan boys should pick one up if they find it at msrp. I do have to say though, the price tag on this bottle is a bit too steep. Jack Daniel's 14 year is $149 MERP. Jim Beam’s Hardin’s Creek line, the 184 month and 211 month 15 & 17.5 year releases were below $175 MSRP..I'm not sure how WT justifies these succeedingly increasing prices. I paid MSRP for this bottle. I would not touch it at secondary prices.

## Rating (t8ke scale)
## 8.8 Excellent, really quite exceptional

1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out

2 | Poor | I wouldn’t consume by choice

3 | Bad | Multiple flaws

4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I’d rather have

5 | Good | Good, just fine

6 | Very Good | A cut above

7 | Great | Well above average

8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional

9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite

10 | Perfect | Perfect

![[IMG_0970.jpg]]

![[IMG_0971.jpg]]

obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.title: Review 4 - Bomberger's PFG 2024 Release
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.content:
### Initial Thoughts
From the first pour, you can tell this Bomberger’s is something different. The French oak finish adds a smooth, rounded sweetness that hits before you even take a sip. Amaretto, maple-brown sugar, and a touch of candied orange, all wrapped in warm spice and seasoned oak. Knowing those barrels spent years air-drying by the Charente River makes sense once you taste it. There’s a calm, mature character that ties everything together. It’s rich, layered, and Bombergers-y.


#### Glass: Glencairn - Rested for: 30 minutes

#### Proof: 100.2

#### Age: NAS

#### Mashbill: Undisclosed

#### Appearance: Amber red

## Nose
The nose opens with a wave of amaretto and maple-brown sugar, followed by warm notes of sweet corn and candied orange peel. Layers of seasoned oak and worn leather ground the profile, while a lively mix of cinnamon, clove, allspice, and black pepper add a refined, spicy edge.

## Palate
The palate mirrors the nose beautifully. Amaretto leads the way, followed by waves of maple brown sugar and baking spice cinnamon, allspice, and a crack of black pepper. Leather and well seasoned oak round out the experience, giving structure and balance to the sweetness. Exceptionally cohesive and well balanced. 

## Finish
Drying, medium long finish ( ~25 seconds) of seasoned oak, leather, and lingering baking spice. Sweet traces of amaretto and maple are present before tapering into dry peppered oak. Great finish for a 100 proofer.

## Final Thoughts
This one hits all the right notes, sweet, spicy, oaky, and just plain satisfying. It feels classic and dusty but with a touch of polish that makes it special. A great example of what Bomberger’s does best.

## Rating (t8ke scale)
## 7.8 Great, well above average

1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out

2 | Poor | I wouldn’t consume by choice

3 | Bad | Multiple flaws

4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I’d rather have

5 | Good | Good, just fine

6 | Very Good | A cut above

7 | Great | Well above average

8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional

9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite

10 | Perfect | Perfect



![[IMG_0966.jpg]]

![[IMG_0968.jpg]]

![[IMG_0969.jpg]]

obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 3 - Jack Daniel's Heritage Toasted Barrel.md
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.title: Review 3 - Jack Daniel's Heritage Toasted Barrel
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.content:
### Initial Thoughts
Being a JD fanboy, I was pretty excited to hear that Jack Daniel’s was releasing a regular shelf whiskey with a toasted profile and real age behind it, and it didn’t disappoint. This release uses the classic Tennessee Whiskey recipe but with **Heritage barrels** toasted twice as long before ( ~24 minutes I believe) a quick char. The whiskey enters at a lower **100 proof**, ages for **seven years** in hotter, higher warehouses, and is **non-chill filtered** before being bottled back at **100 proof**. The final product is a richer, more caramelized sweetness and deeper oak character than their standard lineup.


#### Glass: Glencairn - Rested for: 20 minutes

#### Proof: 100

#### Age: 8 years 2 months 6 days

#### Mashbill: 80% Corn, 12% Malted Barley, 8% Rye

#### Appearance: Dark amber

## Nose
Bubblegum, brown sugar, vanilla, toasted marshmallow. Spiced with black pepper and nutmeg, then grounded by leather and charred oak. A hint of caramelized banana is apparent when you dig for it. It's pure liquid dessert.

## Palate
Rich waves of **toasted marshmallow** dipped in **brown sugar**, finished with a silky **vanilla cream drizzle**. Intensely sweet and dessert like, but still well balanced. The **banana** fades here, but its absence doesn’t detract from the decadent character.

## Finish
A warm surge post swallow that melts into **maple-drizzled brown sugar** and soft char. Short to medium about 15 seconds, which feels right for 100 proof.

## Final Thoughts
My first reaction was, thank goodness I grabbed a backup. Jack Daniel’s is putting out some seriously quality juice here. I’d love to see this at a higher proof, though that might push it into Coy Hill territory. The Heritage Barrel Toasted reminds me of the Jack Daniel’s 12 Year, sharing similar oak depth and sweet notes, but with far less banana. If you spot a bottle, it’s absolutely worth picking up.

## Rating (t8ke scale)
## 8.2 Really quite exceptional

1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out

2 | Poor | I wouldn’t consume by choice

3 | Bad | Multiple flaws

4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I’d rather have

5 | Good | Good, just fine

6 | Very Good | A cut above

7 | Great | Well above average

8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional

9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite

10 | Perfect | Perfect

![[IMG_0954.jpeg]]

![[IMG_0955.jpeg]]

![[IMG_0956.jpeg]]

obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 2 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 & 211 month.md
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.title: Review 2 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 & 211 month
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.content:
#### Glass: Glencairn - rested for 1h

#### 184mo Proof : 108 (54% ABV)

#### 211mo Proof: 109 (54.5% ABV)

#### 185mo Age: 15 & 16 year old blend

#### 211mo Age:  17.58 years old (youngest component)

#### Mashbill: Undisclosed

#### Appearance: The 211 month is a shade darker in proper lighting. The pictures might not do justice regarding color accuracy. Nonetheless, I would have expected these to be a tad darker for their age statements. 

I am fortunate enough to have found these bottles at acceptable secondary pricesa while back. I paid $230 for each 184 month, $260 for each of the 211's. These Jim Beam releases have flown under the radar, and after reading @u/vexmythocrut’s review today, I was reminded that I should get doing what I said I would do: review the 184 & 211 month HC's side by side. This has been a great review to write, knowing that these two are my #1 and #2 bottles in my collection. For context, here are the supposed mashbills:

### **Jacob’s Well 184-month**
- Blend of:
    - **High-rye bourbon mashbill** (78% corn, 12% rye, 10% malted barley) aged 15 years
    - **Traditional bourbon mashbill** (75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley) aged 16 years
### **Jacob’s Well 211-month**
- Blend of:
    - **High-rye bourbon mashbill** (78% corn, 12% rye, 10% malted barley) aged 17 years and 7 months
    - **Traditional bourbon mashbill** (75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley) aged 17 years and 7 months

### 184 Month:
## Nose
The nose on this has opened up from the last time I remember. A cherry cola/caramel note hits me right up front, which weirdly I didn’t get the first go around — maybe reading @u/vexmythocrut’s review of the 184mo today influenced me. Next comes a deep, rich raspberry/cherry compote wrapped in well-aged oak, consistent with my last review. I’ll reiterate from my initial notes: it’s still got that marzipan note I really enjoy. To round it off, there’s freshly ground black pepper, tobacco leaf, full-grain leather, and a bit of rye spice wrapped in a blanket of well-aged oak.

## Palate
From my last post, still stands: Well aged oak right off the bat, then a wave of deep dark brown sugar glaze on a thin wafer of well seasoned oak. You get that deep rich oak character. Then on the mid-palate I get notes of star anise and light clove as well as a sweet dark plum, dates, nutmeg and raisins. There is absolutley nothing sharp about this pour, it is balanced and the age really mellows it out on the palate. Imagine a graceful samurai, precise and controlled, striking with elegance rather than force. That’s this bourbon.. layered, patient, and confident without needing to shout.

## Finish
I stand by what I have written before in my previous review: The finish is lingering, but not too extended, a characteristic I would attribute to a much higher proof offering. But with that, it's still very pleasant. On the back end, the seasoned oak comes through alongside subtle notes of clove and star anise. There’s also a fleeting hint of fruit, like licking the spoon you used to stir a raspberry/cherry compote, warm, spiced, and faintly sweet.

### 211 Month:
## Nose
First thing I notice is that the ethanol is a bit subdued on the 211 compared to the 184, which is typical of higher age stated bourbons. The next scent I am hit with is a giant wave of expertly aged oak, followed by the same cherry cola note that's present on the 184 month. I am getting more fresh black pepper here, more leather, allspice, nutmeg, a bit of clove, and stewed figs, all harmoniously coming together like freshly baked cherry spice cake infused with warm nutmeg, clove, and allspice, topped with rich dried figs, and served beside a drizzle of pepper-infused caramel. The bouquet on this pour is amazing.

## Palate
Viscous, oily, and silky smooth. The mid-palate unfolds with layers of nuanced oak, followed by a rich cherry cola jam spread over a graham cracker, accented by freshly ground black pepper, nutmeg, clove, allspice, and a touch of molasses drizzle. If I were to relate the 211 month to a figure, they would be elegant, bold, and deeply layered, a gentleman of many stories.

## Finish
Finish is a tad bit longer than the 184mo, but truthfully, I'm spliting hairs here. There is a star anise note on this that I really enjoy, it lasts longer than the 184 mo. I also pick up a bit more leather and tobacco, which adds a pleasant richness. The finish is not too drying but you notice the oak tannins leaving your tounge a little parched, a quality that, to me, only adds character.

### Thoughts
This comparison llustrates how those extra 2-3 years transform a bourbon. While the 184-month shows elegance and balance, the 211-month demonstrates what patience can achieve. That subdued ethanol, enhanced viscosity, and deeper oak integration suggest a whiskey that's reached a different level of maturity. Considerign value, if you can get these at msrp, and given their age statements, these Hardin's Creek releases are on the premium end of the spectrum. The question becomes whether the marginal improvements in the 211-month (slightly longer finish, more integrated nose, silkier mouthfeel) justify what's likely a significant price premium. For collectors, probably yes. For drinkers, it might depend on the actual price delta.

As a last note, these are bottles that demand contemplation, not consumption. The kind you pour for those who can appreciate the decades of patience in each glass. Thank you for reading!!

### 184 month

Thank you for reading!! 184 month Rating (t8ke scale) 9.4 - incredible 1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out 2 | Poor | I wouldn’t consume by choice 3 | Bad | Multiple flaws 4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I’d rather have 5 | Good | Good, just fine 6 | Very Good | A cut above 7 | Great | Well above average 8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional 9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite 10 | Perfect | Perfect 211 month Rating (t8ke scale) 9.6 - incredible 1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out 2 | Poor | I wouldn’t consume by choice 3 | Bad | Multiple flaws 4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I’d rather have 5 | Good | Good, just fine 6 | Very Good | A cut above 7 | Great | Well above average 8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional 9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite 10 | Perfect | Perfect !DCB76B8C-49F7-476B-8FA9-E31A36339E11 1.jpeg!474893FC-E8E1-4950-90C5-952F54085B76.jpeg!F411E640-B811-4F98-AA1C-DDF5A1ECF8B9 1.jpeg!662E552A-8C4B-41E1-9907-D3B243AE00BC.jpeg!DB798307-2DFC-49F2-85AE-124B0D9B07821201a.jpeg!D93A9725-177C-4B9F-A5B5-794F038FB8DA1201a.jpeg!Old and refined dudes sipping bourbon.png !Old and refined dudes sipping bourbon 2.png

obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 1 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month.md
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.title: Review 1 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month
obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Revi.content:
![[IMG_7008.jpeg]]


![[IMG_7012.jpeg]]

![[IMG_7015.jpeg]]

![[ChatGPT Image May 18, 2025, 07_52_10 PM.png]]

Hey all! Loooong time lurker here, and as you can see from the title, this is my first ever review. I never thought I would write a review, but that's before I had the great pleasure of having a couple of pours of Jim Beam's (yes it's a Jim Beam product) Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month aged bourbon. This offering from Beam is incorporates 15y and 16y aged whiskey from two mashbills both from JB. Part the HC -JW 184mo whiskey comes from the mashbill from JB's main offerings of Jim Beam, Knob Creek, and Bookers. The other blended whiskey comes from the high rye mashbill of the Old Grand Dad line.


#### Glass: Glencairn - rested for 1h

#### Proof: 108 (54% ABV)

#### Age: 15 & 16 year old blend

#### Mashbill: Undisclosed

#### Appearance: Not as dark as I would have expected for a 15y+ product but still asemi-dark rich amber color.

## Nose
The first scent i get on the nose is a deep and rich raspberry/cherry compote wrapped in well aged oak. One thing this nose reminds me of is a toasted bearclaw pastry that's filled with almond paste or marzipan. But image it coming out of a toaster oven, where you get that burnt sugar smell/marzipan smell...just heavenly. Digging deep in the nose I get some star anise and I a faint hint of the rye spice. 

## Palate
Well aged oak right off the bat, then a wave of deep dark brown sugar glaze on a thin wafer of well seasoned oak. You get that deep rich oak character. Then on the mid-palate I get notes of star anise and light clove as well as a sweet dark plum, dates, nutmeg and raisins. There is absolutley nothing sharp about this pour, it is balanced and the age really mellows it out on the palate. Imagine a graceful samurai, precise and controlled, striking with elegance rather than force. That’s this bourbon.. layered, patient, and confident without needing to shout.

## Finish
The finish is lingering, but not too extended, a characteristic I would attribute to a much higher proof offering. But with that, it's still very pleasant. On the back end, the seasoned oak comes through alongside subtle notes of clove and star anise. There’s also a fleeting hint of fruit, like licking the spoon you used to stir a raspberry/cherry compote, warm, spiced, and faintly sweet.

## Thoughts
Like I said, I've been contempt with lingering around this subreddit for sometime but I have never gotten the urge to write a post until this whiskey graced my lips. It is such a well made bourbon that I felt compelled enough to tell you guys/gals about it. Anywho, after I had the first couple pours of this, I went to my local liquor store and bought the backup of this bottle. I couldn't resist the urge. I am really curious as to how the HC Jacob's Well batch 2 - 211 month stacks up against this. I will have to blind them down the road. I would be amazed if it is THAT much better. Thanks for reading. Cheers! 🍻

## Rating (t8ke scale)
## 9.4 - incredible

1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out

2 | Poor | I wouldn’t consume by choice

3 | Bad | Multiple flaws

4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I’d rather have

5 | Good | Good, just fine

6 | Very Good | A cut above

7 | Great | Well above average

8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional

9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite

10 | Perfect | Perfect

obsidian.main.vault/Ubuntu/Updating Graf.title: Updating Grafana Docker
obsidian.main.vault/Ubuntu/Updating Graf.content:
To update your Grafana Docker container, you can follow these general steps. This method assumes you are using Docker directly or Docker Compose for orchestrating your containers. Here's a step-by-step guide for both approaches:

### For Docker Directly:

1. **Pull the Latest Grafana Image** First, pull the latest version of Grafana from the Docker Hub:
    
    bash
    
    Copy code
    
    `docker pull grafana/grafana:latest`
    
2. **Stop the Current Container** If your Grafana container is running, stop it:
    
    bash
    
    Copy code
    
    `docker stop your-grafana-container`
    
3. **Remove the Old Container** Once the container is stopped, you can remove it:
    
    bash
    
    Copy code
    
    `docker rm your-grafana-container`
    
4. **Start the New Container** Run a new instance of Grafana with the same configuration as before:
    
    bash
    
    Copy code
    
    `docker run -d \   -p 3000:3000 \   --name=your-grafana-container \   -v grafana-storage:/var/lib/grafana \   grafana/grafana:latest`
    
    Replace `-p 3000:3000` with your port settings and `grafana-storage` with your actual volume name if it's different.

obsidian.main.vault/Somacis Screening Ca.title: Somacis
obsidian.main.vault/Somacis Screening Ca.content:
# Somacis × CMMC Level 2 — Recruiter Call Crib Sheet (Markdown Edition)

Quick, practical talking points tailored to a defense-focused PCB manufacturer in Poway/San Diego.

---

## Somacis context (why CMMC Level 2 matters)
- Somacis builds high‑reliability PCBs for aerospace/defense, avionics, and medical. Certifications like **AS9100/ISO 9001**, **ITAR registration**, and **NADCAP** imply likely exposure to **Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI)**.
- CUI typically touches **engineering (CAD/CAM: Gerber/ODB++)**, **PLM/ERP/MES**, **secure file transfer** with primes, and **limited vendor access**—prime candidates for a **scoped CUI enclave**.

## CMMC quick facts (Level 2)
- CMMC = DoD’s cybersecurity maturity program for contractors.
- **Level 2 aligns to NIST SP 800‑171** practices to protect CUI; **C3PAO certification** is expected as contracts phase in.
- DFARS backbone you’ll hear: **252.204‑7012** (implement 800‑171 + incident reporting), **252.204‑7019/7020** (post score in **SPRS**; DoD can validate), **252.204‑7021** (activates CMMC in contracts).

## What Level 2 looks like at a PCB manufacturer
- **Scope & Enclave:** Define a **CUI enclave** for engineering workstations/servers, **PLM/ERP/MES**, and **MFT/SFTP** portals; segment from **corporate IT** and **OT** lines (lamination/etch/CNC).
- **Access & Identity (AC/IA):** MFA everywhere, least‑privilege roles, privileged access workflows, time‑bound vendor accounts, session/timeouts on remote support.
- **Configuration & Patch (CM/SA/MA):** CIS‑aligned baselines; gold images for engineering/MES; change control tied to tickets and the **SSP/POA&M**.
- **Logging/Monitoring & IR (AU/SI/IR):** Centralize logs (AD, file servers, firewalls, MES); alert on abnormal CUI access; rehearse incident response with evidence capture.
- **Data Handling (MP/SC):** Mark/classify CUI; control removable media on shop floor; DLP on engineering shares; encrypt data at rest and in transit; vetted MFT.

## Evidence & artifacts recruiters expect you to mention
- **System Security Plan (SSP)** + **network/data‑flow diagrams** for the CUI enclave.
- **POA&M** with tracked remediation; current DoD Assessment/**SPRS score**.
- Operational proof: **tickets, baseline configs, MFA/IdP settings, SIEM alerts, vulnerability scans, patch reports, backup/restore tests, vendor access logs**.

## 30‑60‑90 for a Tier 2–3 Sysadmin (sound bite)
- **30d:** Confirm DFARS clauses in play, identify CUI data flows, freeze scope for the enclave, baseline MFA and logging coverage.
- **60d:** Close high‑impact gaps (admin MFA, log retention, least‑privilege), finalize CIS builds, stand up **artifact library** tied to SSP controls.
- **90d:** Harden vendor access, DLP for engineering, drill IR with evidence capture, improve **SPRS score** and **POA&M burn‑down** cadence.

## Smart Somacis‑specific questions (to show you ‘get it’)
- **CUI scope:** Which users/systems are in the enclave today (CAD/CAM, PLM/ERP/MES, supplier portals)? How is it segmented from corporate IT and OT?
- **Assessment:** Are you pursuing **C3PAO certification** or operating under **self‑assessment** right now? What’s your current artifact set per the L2 Assessment Guide?
- **Tooling:** Which **SIEM/EDR/MDM** cover engineering and shop‑floor endpoints? How do you collect and map evidence to **800‑171** practices (tickets, configs, reports)?
- **Export controls:** Given **ITAR**, how do you separate **ITAR vs CUI** handling (visitor controls, foreign‑national access, data segregation)?

## One‑liner opener
> “Somacis is a defense‑focused PCB manufacturer in Poway. For CMMC L2, I’d help run a tightly scoped CUI enclave around engineering and shop‑floor systems, lock down identity and baselines, centralize logging, and keep an audit‑ready SSP/POA&M tied to ticketed change and remediation.”

## Mini glossary (fast refresh)
- **CUI:** Controlled Unclassified Information—data requiring safeguarding in non‑federal systems.
- **CMMC L2:** DoD program level aligning with NIST SP 800‑171 practices for CUI; typically requires C3PAO certification.
- **SSP:** System Security Plan describing how each practice is implemented.
- **POA&M:** Plan of Action & Milestones—tracked gaps and remediation plan tied to owners/dates.
- **SPRS:** Supplier Performance Risk System where your **NIST 800‑171** score is posted per **DFARS 7019/7020**.

---

# “Evidence‑forward” examples (what artifact I’d show for each control I discuss)

Below are concrete artifacts you can cite *on the call*—organized by **NIST 800‑171 Rev. 2** control families (3.x). Each line is a quick “control → artifact” pairing.

### Access Control (AC – 3.1)
- **AC.L1‑3.1.1/AC.L2‑3.1.2 (Limit access to authorized users/roles):** Role matrix for engineering/MES, AD security group membership export, access request/approval tickets.
- **AC.L2‑3.1.5 (Least privilege):** Baseline GPO set enforcing restricted local admin; PAM workflow screenshots for privileged sessions; SOP for just‑in‑time elevation.
- **AC.L2‑3.1.12 (Session control):** IdP policy screenshot showing inactivity timeouts; RDP/SSH idle timeout configs; VPN portal session lifetimes.

### Awareness & Training (AT – 3.2)
- **AT.L2‑3.2.1 (Security awareness for CUI):** LMS completion report for CUI/ITAR training; training curriculum; acknowledgement records.
- **AT.L2‑3.2.2 (Role‑based training):** MES operator training checklist; admin runbooks for enclave procedures.

### Audit & Accountability (AU – 3.3)
- **AU.L2‑3.3.1/3.3.2 (Generate & retain logs):** SIEM data source inventory; retention settings (e.g., 12 months hot + archive); sample log showing CUI access event.
- **AU.L2‑3.3.6 (Audit review/alert):** Correlation rule for anomalous access to engineering share; alert runbook; weekly audit review ticket with findings.
- **AU.L2‑3.3.7 (Time stamps & sync):** NTP config for domain controllers; SIEM event time‑sync verification.

### Configuration Management (CM – 3.4)
- **CM.L2‑3.4.1 (Baseline configurations):** CIS hardening checklist + GPO backup; gold image manifest for CAD/MES workstations.
- **CM.L2‑3.4.3 (Track/approve changes):** Change tickets with risk/rollback sections; CAB meeting notes; config diff artifact (before/after).
- **CM.L2‑3.4.6 (Least functionality):** App allow‑list policy; PowerShell Constrained Language Mode proof; disabled services list.

### Identification & Authentication (IA – 3.5)
- **IA.L2‑3.5.1 (Identify users):** Central IdP directory export (users, service accts), joiners‑movers‑leavers workflow.
- **IA.L2‑3.5.3/3.5.7 (MFA for network & privileged use):** IdP policy screenshot for MFA groups; VPN/Privileged Access Gateway MFA configs; privileged admin MFA test log.
- **IA.L2‑3.5.6 (Password mgmt):** GPO enforcing length/complexity/lockout; vault policy for service credentials; rotation evidence.

### Incident Response (IR – 3.6)
- **IR.L2‑3.6.1 (IR policy & roles):** IR plan excerpt with roles/contacts; RACI chart for 7012 reporting.
- **IR.L2‑3.6.2/3.6.3 (Test & track incidents):** Tabletop exercise report for CUI exfil scenario; post‑incident ticket with timeline and lessons learned.
- **IR.L2‑3.6.4 (Report to external orgs):** Template for DoD reporting via DIBNet portal; evidence of 72‑hour internal escalation workflow.

### Maintenance (MA – 3.7)
- **MA.L2‑3.7.2 (Controlled maintenance):** Vendor access SOP; pre‑approved remote support windows; maintenance logs tied to tickets.
- **MA.L2‑3.7.5 (Remote maintenance authorization):** Session recording setting on remote tools; time‑bound vendor accounts; connection approval records.

### Media Protection (MP – 3.8)
- **MP.L2‑3.8.1/3.8.2 (Protect & mark media):** CUI marking guide; DLP policy on engineering share; removable media encryption policy; media logs.
- **MP.L2‑3.8.7 (Media sanitization):** Sanitization SOP (NIST 800‑88 mapping); destruction certificates.

### Personnel Security (PS – 3.9)
- **PS.L2‑3.9.1 (Screening):** HR checklist for background screens for enclave roles.
- **PS.L2‑3.9.2 (Termination/transfer):** Leaver checklist with account disable timelines; device return forms.

### Physical Protection (PE – 3.10)
- **PE.L2‑3.10.1/3.10.3 (Limit physical access/monitor):** Badge access reports for engineering lab; camera retention policy; visitor logs with citizenship tracking (ITAR context).

### Risk Assessment (RA – 3.11)
- **RA.L2‑3.11.1/3.11.2 (Periodic risk assessments & scans):** Quarterly risk register; authenticated vuln scan reports; remediation SLAs and trend chart.
- **RA.L2‑3.11.3 (Remediate vulnerabilities):** POA&M items referencing CVEs with owners/dates; patch rollout tickets.

### Security Assessment (CA – 3.12)
- **CA.L2‑3.12.1 (Assess periodically):** Internal assessment report mapped to 800‑171 controls; **SPRS score** submission screenshot.
- **CA.L2‑3.12.2 (Develop/track POA&M):** Live POA&M spreadsheet/dashboard; burn‑down metrics.
- **CA.L2‑3.12.4 (SSP updates):** Versioned SSP with change log; data‑flow diagram updates for new MES module.

### System & Communications Protection (SC – 3.13)
- **SC.L2‑3.13.8 (Encrypt CUI in transit):** TLS configs for MFT/SFTP; HSTS setting; cipher suite scan results.
- **SC.L2‑3.13.10 (Boundary protection):** Firewall policy export; segmentation diagram between enclave, corporate IT, and OT; rule review ticket.
- **SC.L2‑3.13.16 (Protect confidentiality of CUI at rest):** Disk encryption policy (BitLocker/FileVault/LUKS); storage key mgmt screenshots; database TDE config.

### System & Information Integrity (SI – 3.14)
- **SI.L2‑3.14.1 (Flaw remediation):** Patch cadence policy; WSUS/MDM compliance report; out‑of‑band patch ticket for zero‑day.
- **SI.L2‑3.14.3 (Malware protection):** EDR policy; detection event record; weekly health report.
- **SI.L2‑3.14.6 (Monitor & alert):** SIEM correlation rule for unusual CAD file exfil; sample alert with analyst notes; tuning change record.

---

### How to use this during the call
- When a control comes up, lead with: **“We do X, and the artifact I’d show is Y.”**
- Keep a small list of **screenshots, tickets, and exports** handy to name‑drop: *IdP MFA policy*, *SIEM retention page*, *CIS baseline checklist*, *POA&M spreadsheet*, *SPRS confirmation*, *change tickets with rollbacks*, *segmentation diagrams*.






## Questions

## Role & Expectations
- What are the top 2–3 outcomes you’d want this person to deliver in the first 90 days?
- How is success measured in this role (metrics, milestones, or examples of “what good looks like”)?
- Why is the position open—new headcount or backfill? What prompted the need now?
- What does a typical week look like for this role (meetings vs. focus time, interruptions, after-hours)?

## Team & Culture
- Where does this role sit in the org chart, and who would I partner with most (IT, Engineering, Quality/AS9100, Operations)?
- How would you describe the team’s culture and communication style?
- What qualities do people who thrive here tend to share?

## Process & Maturity (without the tech deep dive)
- How far along is the company in its current compliance journey, and what phase is this team focused on this year?
- Do you have a clear roadmap for the next 6–12 months, and how does this role contribute?
- How are priorities set and trade-offs made when new requests come in?

## Onboarding & Support
- What does onboarding look like in the first month?
- Are there documented playbooks or checklists I’d inherit?
- How do you approach professional development—courses, certifications, or conference attendance?

## Cross-Functional Collaboration
- Which departments are the most important partners for this role (e.g., Quality/AS9100, Operations, Engineering)?
- What’s working well in those partnerships, and what could be improved?

## Work Model & Logistics
- Is the role onsite, hybrid, or flexible? If hybrid, what cadence do you expect?
- Any travel expectations between facilities or to customer sites?

## Leadership & Decision-Making
- How involved are managers in day-to-day decisions versus empowering ICs to run with things?
- How are big decisions communicated to the team?

## Career Path
- What potential paths could this role lead to in 1–2 years (lead, architect, compliance program manager, etc.)?
- How do internal moves or promotions typically work?

## Compensation & Benefits *(use if appropriate)*
- What salary band has been approved for this role?
- How are bonuses or performance incentives structured?
- Any stand-out benefits or perks (education support, certification reimbursement, PTO practices)?

## Hiring Process & Next Steps
- What are the next interview steps and who would I meet with?
- Is there anything in my background you’d like me to clarify for the hiring team?
- What’s your target start timeline?
"""
file_path = "/mnt/data/Recruiter_Screening_Questions.md"
with open(file_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(content)

file_path
obsidian.main.vault/Somacis Screening Ca.cleanContent: Somacis × CMMC Level 2 — Recruiter Call Crib Sheet (Markdown Edition) Quick, practical talking points tailored to a defense-focused PCB manufacturer in Poway/San Diego. “Evidence‑forward” examples (what artifact I’d show for each control I discuss) Below are concrete artifacts you can cite on the call—organized by NIST 800‑171 Rev. 2 control families (3.x). Each line is a quick “control → artifact” pairing. Access Control (AC – 3.1) AC.L1‑3.1.1/AC.L2‑3.1.2 (Limit access to authorized users/roles): Role matrix for engineering/MES, AD security group membership export, access request/approval tickets. AC.L2‑3.1.5 (Least privilege): Baseline GPO set enforcing restricted local admin; PAM workflow screenshots for privileged sessions; SOP for just‑in‑time elevation. AC.L2‑3.1.12 (Session control): IdP policy screenshot showing inactivity timeouts; RDP/SSH idle timeout configs; VPN portal session lifetimes. Awareness & Training (AT – 3.2) AT.L2‑3.2.1 (Security awareness for CUI): LMS completion report for CUI/ITAR training; training curriculum; acknowledgement records. AT.L2‑3.2.2 (Role‑based training): MES operator training checklist; admin runbooks for enclave procedures. Audit & Accountability (AU – 3.3) AU.L2‑3.3.1/3.3.2 (Generate & retain logs): SIEM data source inventory; retention settings (e.g., 12 months hot + archive); sample log showing CUI access event. AU.L2‑3.3.6 (Audit review/alert): Correlation rule for anomalous access to engineering share; alert runbook; weekly audit review ticket with findings. AU.L2‑3.3.7 (Time stamps & sync): NTP config for domain controllers; SIEM event time‑sync verification. Configuration Management (CM – 3.4) CM.L2‑3.4.1 (Baseline configurations): CIS hardening checklist + GPO backup; gold image manifest for CAD/MES workstations. CM.L2‑3.4.3 (Track/approve changes): Change tickets with risk/rollback sections; CAB meeting notes; config diff artifact (before/after). CM.L2‑3.4.6 (Least functionality): App allow‑list policy; PowerShell Constrained Language Mode proof; disabled services list. Identification & Authentication (IA – 3.5) IA.L2‑3.5.1 (Identify users): Central IdP directory export (users, service accts), joiners‑movers‑leavers workflow. IA.L2‑3.5.3/3.5.7 (MFA for network & privileged use): IdP policy screenshot for MFA groups; VPN/Privileged Access Gateway MFA configs; privileged admin MFA test log. IA.L2‑3.5.6 (Password mgmt): GPO enforcing length/complexity/lockout; vault policy for service credentials; rotation evidence. Incident Response (IR – 3.6) IR.L2‑3.6.1 (IR policy & roles): IR plan excerpt with roles/contacts; RACI chart for 7012 reporting. IR.L2‑3.6.2/3.6.3 (Test & track incidents): Tabletop exercise report for CUI exfil scenario; post‑incident ticket with timeline and lessons learned. IR.L2‑3.6.4 (Report to external orgs): Template for DoD reporting via DIBNet portal; evidence of 72‑hour internal escalation workflow. Maintenance (MA – 3.7) MA.L2‑3.7.2 (Controlled maintenance): Vendor access SOP; pre‑approved remote support windows; maintenance logs tied to tickets. MA.L2‑3.7.5 (Remote maintenance authorization): Session recording setting on remote tools; time‑bound vendor accounts; connection approval records. Media Protection (MP – 3.8) MP.L2‑3.8.1/3.8.2 (Protect & mark media): CUI marking guide; DLP policy on engineering share; removable media encryption policy; media logs. MP.L2‑3.8.7 (Media sanitization): Sanitization SOP (NIST 800‑88 mapping); destruction certificates. Personnel Security (PS – 3.9) PS.L2‑3.9.1 (Screening): HR checklist for background screens for enclave roles. PS.L2‑3.9.2 (Termination/transfer): Leaver checklist with account disable timelines; device return forms. Physical Protection (PE – 3.10) PE.L2‑3.10.1/3.10.3 (Limit physical access/monitor): Badge access reports for engineering lab; camera retention policy; visitor logs with citizenship tracking (ITAR context). Risk Assessment (RA – 3.11) RA.L2‑3.11.1/3.11.2 (Periodic risk assessments & scans): Quarterly risk register; authenticated vuln scan reports; remediation SLAs and trend chart. RA.L2‑3.11.3 (Remediate vulnerabilities): POA&M items referencing CVEs with owners/dates; patch rollout tickets. Security Assessment (CA – 3.12) CA.L2‑3.12.1 (Assess periodically): Internal assessment report mapped to 800‑171 controls; SPRS score submission screenshot. CA.L2‑3.12.2 (Develop/track POA&M): Live POA&M spreadsheet/dashboard; burn‑down metrics. CA.L2‑3.12.4 (SSP updates): Versioned SSP with change log; data‑flow diagram updates for new MES module. System & Communications Protection (SC – 3.13) SC.L2‑3.13.8 (Encrypt CUI in transit): TLS configs for MFT/SFTP; HSTS setting; cipher suite scan results. SC.L2‑3.13.10 (Boundary protection): Firewall policy export; segmentation diagram between enclave, corporate IT, and OT; rule review ticket. SC.L2‑3.13.16 (Protect confidentiality of CUI at rest): Disk encryption policy (BitLocker/FileVault/LUKS); storage key mgmt screenshots; database TDE config. System & Information Integrity (SI – 3.14) SI.L2‑3.14.1 (Flaw remediation): Patch cadence policy; WSUS/MDM compliance report; out‑of‑band patch ticket for zero‑day. SI.L2‑3.14.3 (Malware protection): EDR policy; detection event record; weekly health report. SI.L2‑3.14.6 (Monitor & alert): SIEM correlation rule for unusual CAD file exfil; sample alert with analyst notes; tuning change record. How to use this during the call When a control comes up, lead with: “We do X, and the artifact I’d show is Y.” Keep a small list of screenshots, tickets, and exports handy to name‑drop: IdP MFA policy, SIEM retention page, CIS baseline checklist, POA&M spreadsheet, SPRS confirmation, change tickets with rollbacks, segmentation diagrams. Questions Role & Expectations What are the top 2–3 outcomes you’d want this person to deliver in the first 90 days? How is success measured in this role (metrics, milestones, or examples of “what good looks like”)? Why is the position open—new headcount or backfill? What prompted the need now? What does a typical week look like for this role (meetings vs. focus time, interruptions, after-hours)? Team & Culture Where does this role sit in the org chart, and who would I partner with most (IT, Engineering, Quality/AS9100, Operations)? How would you describe the team’s culture and communication style? What qualities do people who thrive here tend to share? Process & Maturity (without the tech deep dive) How far along is the company in its current compliance journey, and what phase is this team focused on this year? Do you have a clear roadmap for the next 6–12 months, and how does this role contribute? How are priorities set and trade-offs made when new requests come in? Onboarding & Support What does onboarding look like in the first month? Are there documented playbooks or checklists I’d inherit? How do you approach professional development—courses, certifications, or conference attendance? Cross-Functional Collaboration Which departments are the most important partners for this role (e.g., Quality/AS9100, Operations, Engineering)? What’s working well in those partnerships, and what could be improved? Work Model & Logistics Is the role onsite, hybrid, or flexible? If hybrid, what cadence do you expect? Any travel expectations between facilities or to customer sites? Leadership & Decision-Making How involved are managers in day-to-day decisions versus empowering ICs to run with things? How are big decisions communicated to the team? Career Path What potential paths could this role lead to in 1–2 years (lead, architect, compliance program manager, etc.)? How do internal moves or promotions typically work? Compensation & Benefits (use if appropriate) What salary band has been approved for this role? How are bonuses or performance incentives structured? Any stand-out benefits or perks (education support, certification reimbursement, PTO practices)? Hiring Process & Next Steps What are the next interview steps and who would I meet with? Is there anything in my background you’d like me to clarify for the hiring team? What’s your target start timeline? """ filepath = "/mnt/data/RecruiterScreeningQuestions.md" with open(filepath, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f: f.write(content) file_path
headings: Somacis × CMMC Level 2 — Recruiter Call Crib Sheet (Markdown Edition)
What Level 2 looks like at a PCB manufacturer
Evidence & artifacts recruiters expect you to mention
Smart Somacis‑specific questions (to show you ‘get it’)
“Evidence‑forward” examples (what artifact I’d show for each control I discuss)
How to use this during the call
Process & Maturity (without the tech deep dive)

obsidian.main.vault/Resume Write-ups/dra.title: drafts
obsidian.main.vault/Resume Write-ups/dra.content:
Throughout my career, I have gained experience collecting and confirming information from a variety of sources and methods. During my internship at the SANS Internet Storm Center, I deployed a Dshield honeypot that involved capturing key data on attacker tactics and behaviors (TTPs) from various sources. I analyzed this data to create several reports on Dshield Honeypot findings unearthing new insights into cyber threats, and the techniques that attackers were attempting to leverage. This experience taught me the importance of verifying information from different sources to ensure accuracy and reliability. 

Additionally, as a Cybersecurity Engineer at Harmony Blockchain, I conducted crypto wallet theft investigations using log data and ElasticSearch. This required me to collect and analyze information from multiple sources, including log data, network traffic captures, and open-source intelligence (OSINT) to identify patterns and trends that could help in the recovery of stolen funds. I also managed victim communications and ensured that discovered threat vectors were remediated, which further emphasized the need for thorough information collection and verification.

My experience in the United States Marine Corps as a Team Leader also involved gathering and verifying information from various sources, including intelligence reports, surveillance data, and human intelligence, to accurately inform operational decisions and ensure the safety of personnel. 

In all these roles, I have developed a holistic understanding of the importance of collecting and confirming information from a variety of sources and methods, including intelligence databases, reports of investigation, and open sources. I am confident that my skills in data collection, analysis, and verification will enable me to make a valuable contribution to the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency (DCSA) in identifying and mitigating foreign influence and preference concerns.



I have comprehensive experience preparing complex reports throughout my career ranging from my time in project management up to the present moment in cybersecurity. During my internship at the SANS Internet Storm Center, I created several reports on Dshield Honeypot findings, which involved analyzing and interpreting large datasets to detect new insights into cyber threats. These reports required me to present complex technical information in a clear and concise manner, making them accessible to both technical and non-technical stakeholders. 

Additionally at the SANS ISC, I created multiple malware analysis reports on different strains of malware strains from initial infection to full propagation in a given network. 
These reports involved analyzing log data, network traffic captures, and OSINT to identify patterns and trends that could help pinpoint a possible attack vector for exploitation.

During these experiences, I had to present my findings in a clear and actionable way, making sure that stakeholders could understand the technical details and take appropriate remediation steps. 

In my project management roles at Webcor Builders, Canning Electric Inc., and Northrup Building, I was responsible for preparing project reports, RFIs and RFPs including progress updates, budget analyses, and various constructibility assessments. These reports required me to collect and analyze data from different sources, including project schedules, financial records, and stakeholder feedback, and present them in an easy to understand manner to project stakeholders.



**Do you have experience applying difficult and complex assignments in security, law enforcement, and counterintelligence analysis?** 

**If yes, please describe your experience applying difficult and complex assignments in security, law enforcement, and counterintelligence.**

In my role as a Team Leader in the United States Marine Corps, I was involved in two overseas deployments, where I applied my skills in security and counterintelligence analysis to ensure the safety of personnel and assets. These assignments were complex in a sense that they required me to analyze intelligence reports, surveillance data, and human intelligence to identify potential threats and develop appropriate countermeasures. Reports were often vague and not very detailed which, in a lot of cases required additional surveillance and investigation. 


During my internship at the SANS Internet Storm Center, I conducted malware analysis, producing 10+ detailed reports on various malware strains, uncovering their traits and impacts. This assignment was complex and required me to apply my knowledge of reverse engineering, static and dynamic analysis, and malware behavior to identify potential threats and develop appropriate mitigation strategies.As a Team Captain for the SANS.edu Team 935 in the National Cyber League, I led a cybersecurity team in fostering collaboration and effective strategy development. This assignment was complex and required me to apply my knowledge of security best practices, incident response, and team management to guide team members in improving their cybersecurity skills in log analysis and forensic investigations.My experience in applying difficult and complex assignments in security, law enforcement, and counterintelligence analysis has taught me the importance of critical thinking, problem-solving, and adaptability in identifying and mitigating potential threats. I am confident that my skills and experience will enable me to effectively contribute to the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency (DCSA) in identifying and mitigating foreign influence and preference concerns.


**Do you have experience analyzing, compiling, reporting and disseminating intelligence data?**

**If yes, please describe your experience analyzing, compiling, reporting and disseminating intelligence data.** 

Yes, I have experience analyzing, compiling, reporting, and disseminating intelligence data. During my internship at the SANS Internet Storm Center, I investigated various logs, attacker uploads, bash queries and scripts to narrow down and extract interesting leads from Dshield honeypot aggregated data. This involved capturing key data on attacker tactics and behaviors. I analyzed this data to identify trends and patterns, compiling my findings into several reports on malicious attacker patterns and activities. These reports helped uncover new insights into cyber threats which were disseminated to the relevant stakeholders and community users of the SANS Internet Storm Center.

1. Honeypots are devices connected to the internet that act like, for example, an injured animal that attracts predators, in this case, malicious attackers to interact with the honeypot. 
2. Honeypots can detect malicious activities early by observing interactions with decoy systems, diverting attackers from more valuable systems, and keeping actual resources safe.
3. Honeypots collect data on attack methods and techniques, which can be used to analyze attacker behaviors, identify new threats, and improve security measures


  
**Do you have experience reviewing and interpreting counterintelligence and terrorism-related data and reporting?**

**11.If yes, please describe your experience reviewing and interpreting counterintelligence and terrorism-related data and reporting.**

Yes, I have experience reviewing and interpreting counterintelligence and terrorism-related data and reporting, mostly gained during my service in the United States Marine Corps. As a Team Leader with two overseas deployments to Helmand Province, Afghanistan, I was responsible for analyzing multiple sources of intelligence reports, including Palantir, that included data on potential suspects, terrorist activities, and counterintelligence threats. My team leader role required me to effectively assess and interpret intelligence reports to ensure the safety and security of my squad and platoon and to be able inform strategic decisions, especially for upcoming patrol missions. My military training provided me with the skills to comprehend and interpret intelligence reports, identify potential threats, and communicate findings in an easy to understand manner to command and team members. This foundation in intelligence analysis is further strengthened by my cybersecurity education and certifications, allowing me to handle sophisticated security challenges in diverse environments.

obsidian.main.vault/PayPal - Offensive S.title: Test 1
obsidian.main.vault/PayPal - Offensive S.content:
Okay, this is a great way to solidify your knowledge! I'll create a test that covers the key areas from the study guide.

**Instructions:**

*   Try to answer these from memory first.
*   Then, review your answers against the study guide or other resources.
*   For scenario questions, think about your methodology and the tools you'd use.
*   The goal isn't just to get them right, but to understand *why* an answer is correct.

---

**Offensive Security Engineer - Knowledge Test**

**Section 1: Network Infrastructure Security (40 Points)**

1.  **(Multiple Choice - 2 pts)** Which Nmap scan type is often referred to as a "stealth scan" because it doesn't complete the TCP three-way handshake?
    a) `nmap -sT <target>` (TCP Connect Scan)
    b) `nmap -sS <target>` (SYN Scan)
    c) `nmap -sU <target>` (UDP Scan)
    d) `nmap -sA <target>` (ACK Scan)

2.  **(Short Answer - 3 pts)** You run `nmap -sV -p- --script vuln <target_IP>`. Briefly explain what information each part of this command aims to gather (`-sV`, `-p-`, `--script vuln`).

3.  **(Scenario - 5 pts)** You've identified an SMB service (port 445) open on a Windows host. Describe at least three enumeration steps you would take and the tools you might use.

4.  **(Explanation - 4 pts)** Explain the concept of ARP spoofing and what an attacker can achieve with it.

5.  **(Short Answer - 3 pts)** Name two common default community strings for SNMP and what kind of information an attacker might gain by exploiting them.

6.  **(Active Directory - 5 pts)**
    a) What is the primary purpose of the tool BloodHound in an Active Directory assessment?
    b) Briefly explain what Kerberoasting is and why it's effective.

7.  **(Privilege Escalation - 4 pts)** Name one common privilege escalation technique for Linux and one for Windows.

8.  **(Lateral Movement - 4 pts)** You have compromised a web server in the DMZ. What are two distinct methods you might use to attempt lateral movement into the internal corporate network?

9.  **(Explanation - 5 pts)** Explain how a DNS Zone Transfer (AXFR) can be misused by an attacker for reconnaissance. What specific command (using `dig`) would you use to attempt it against `ns1.example.com` for the domain `example.com`?

10. **(Cloud - 5 pts)** An attacker discovers an SSRF vulnerability on a web application hosted in AWS. How might they leverage this SSRF to gain further access or information within the AWS environment? Name a specific target they might try to reach.

**Section 2: Web Application Security (45 Points)**

11. **(OWASP Top 10 - ID - 3 pts)** A web application allows users to view their order details via a URL like `https://shop.com/orders?order_id=1052`. An attacker changes the `order_id` to `1053` and can view another user's order. Which OWASP Top 10 category (A0X:2021 – Name) does this primarily fall under?

12. **(SQL Injection - 5 pts)**
    a) What is the difference between in-band (e.g., error-based, UNION-based) and blind SQL injection?
    b) Name a popular open-source tool used for automating SQL injection attacks.

13. **(XSS - 5 pts)**
    a) Differentiate between Stored XSS and Reflected XSS.
    b) Provide a simple JavaScript payload that could be used to demonstrate a basic XSS vulnerability (e.g., create a pop-up alert).

14. **(Security Misconfiguration - 3 pts)** Give two examples of common security misconfigurations found in web applications or their supporting infrastructure.

15. **(SSRF - 4 pts)** Besides accessing cloud metadata services, what are two other malicious actions an attacker could perform using a Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) vulnerability?

16. **(Authentication/Session - 4 pts)**
    a) What is the purpose of the `HttpOnly` flag on a session cookie?
    b) What is a common vulnerability associated with JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) if not implemented correctly?

17. **(File Upload - 4 pts)** An application allows users to upload profile pictures. What are two security concerns an attacker might try to exploit through this functionality, and how might they attempt it?

18. **(Burp Suite - 5 pts)** Describe the primary function of the following Burp Suite modules:
    a) Repeater
    b) Intruder

19. **(API Security - 4 pts)** What does BOLA (Broken Object Level Authorization) mean in the context of API security (OWASP API Security Top 10)? Give a brief example.

20. **(Methodology - 8 pts)** Briefly outline your general methodology when starting a penetration test against a new, unknown web application. List at least 4 key phases or steps.

**Section 3: General Offensive Security & Mindset (15 Points)**

21. **(Scripting - 3 pts)** Why is Python a popular language for offensive security tasks? Give one example of how you might use a Python script during a penetration test.

22. **(Evasion - 4 pts)** You are trying to exfiltrate data from a compromised host, but you suspect an IDS/IPS is monitoring outbound traffic. Name two techniques you could consider to try and evade detection.

23. **(Problem Solving - Scenario - 5 pts)** You have gained low-privilege shell access on a Linux server. You discover that the `find` command has the SUID bit set and is owned by root. How could you potentially use this to escalate your privileges? (Be specific about the command if possible).

24. **(Keeping Current - 3 pts)** How do you personally stay up-to-date with the latest vulnerabilities, attack techniques, and security tools? Name one resource you find valuable.

---

**Answer Key & Explanations (Self-Check After Attempting)**

**Section 1: Network Infrastructure Security**

1.  **b) `nmap -sS <target>` (SYN Scan)**
2.  `-sV`: Version detection (attempts to determine the version of services running on open ports). `-p-`: Scans all 65535 TCP ports. `--script vuln`: Runs Nmap scripts categorized as 'vuln' to check for known vulnerabilities.
3.  *   **Null Session Enumeration:** `enum4linux <target_IP>` (to get users, shares, OS info).
    *   **List Shares:** `smbclient -L //<target_IP> -N` (anonymous) or with credentials.
    *   **Check for known SMB vulnerabilities:** Using Nmap scripts like `smb-vuln-*` or searching exploit-db.
    *   Attempt to connect to shares like IPC$ or common share names.
4.  ARP spoofing (or ARP poisoning) involves an attacker sending falsified ARP messages onto a local area network. This allows the attacker to associate their MAC address with the IP address of another host (like the default gateway). Consequently, any traffic from victims intended for that IP address is sent to the attacker instead, enabling Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, session hijacking, or traffic sniffing.
5.  `public`, `private`. Attackers can gain system information (OS, uptime, running processes, network interfaces, routing tables), user accounts, network configuration, sometimes even write access if misconfigured.
6.  a) BloodHound visualizes Active Directory environments, mapping relationships between users, groups, computers, GPOs, and ACLs to identify complex attack paths and privilege escalation routes.
    b) Kerberoasting is an attack where an attacker requests service tickets (TGS) for service accounts within Active Directory. If a service account has a weak password, its NTLM hash (derived from the TGS) can be cracked offline. It's effective because service accounts often have high privileges and their passwords are changed less frequently.
7.  *   **Linux:** Exploiting SUID/GUID binaries (e.g., `find` with `-exec`), misconfigured `sudo` permissions, kernel exploits, cron job hijacking.
    *   **Windows:** Unquoted service paths, insecure service permissions, DLL hijacking, token impersonation/theft (e.g., Juicy Potato), AlwaysInstallElevated.
8.  *   **Pivoting using compromised credentials:** If credentials (e.g., local admin hash, service account creds) are found on the DMZ server, try them against internal systems via SSH, RDP, WinRM, SMB.
    *   **Exploiting trust relationships or vulnerabilities:** If the DMZ server can reach internal systems, scan for vulnerabilities on those internal systems and exploit them, or use tools like `chisel` or `ligolo-ng` to create a tunnel/proxy into the internal network.
9.  A DNS Zone Transfer (AXFR) allows an attacker to request a full copy of a domain's DNS records from an authoritative DNS server if it's misconfigured to allow transfers to unauthorized IPs. This reveals a wealth of information like hostnames, IP addresses, service records (SRV), mail servers (MX), etc., effectively mapping out the target's network infrastructure.
    Command: `dig axfr @ns1.example.com example.com`
10. An attacker could leverage SSRF to:
    *   **Access the EC2 Instance Metadata Service (IMDS):** Typically at `http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/`. This can expose instance credentials (IAM roles), user data, network configurations, etc.
    *   Scan internal AWS network ranges or ports on other EC2 instances.
    *   Interact with internal services that the compromised instance has network access to (e.g., internal admin panels, databases without authentication accessible from the instance).

**Section 2: Web Application Security**

11. **A01:2021 – Broken Access Control** (Specifically, this is an example of Insecure Direct Object Reference - IDOR).
12. a) **In-band SQLi:** Data is exfiltrated through the same channel used to inject the SQL code (e.g., results appear directly on the web page or in an error message). **Blind SQLi:** No data is directly returned in the HTTP response. The attacker infers information by asking true/false questions (Boolean-based blind) or by measuring server response times (Time-based blind).
    b) `sqlmap`
13. a) **Stored XSS:** Malicious script is injected and stored permanently on the target server (e.g., in a database, comment field, forum post). Victims view the page containing the script, and it executes in their browser. **Reflected XSS:** Malicious script is injected into a URL parameter or form submission and reflected back to the user from the server in the HTTP response. It requires the victim to click a crafted link or submit a malicious form.
    b) `<script>alert('XSS')</script>` or `<script>alert(document.cookie)</script>`
14. *   Default credentials left unchanged on admin panels or database services.
    *   Directory listing enabled on the web server.
    *   Verbose error messages revealing sensitive information (stack traces, file paths).
    *   Unnecessary services/features enabled (e.g., DEBUG mode in production).
15. *   Port scanning internal networks accessible from the server.
    *   Reading local files from the server (if the SSRF handler supports `file:///` schemas).
    *   Interacting with internal, non-HTTP services if the application logic allows different URL schemes (e.g., `gopher://`).
    *   Performing DoS against other internal/external systems by forcing the server to make many requests.
16. a) The `HttpOnly` flag prevents client-side scripts (like JavaScript) from accessing the cookie, mitigating the impact of XSS attacks that aim to steal session cookies.
    b) Weak secret keys for signing tokens, use of the `alg:none` vulnerability (allowing signature stripping), or storing sensitive data directly in the JWT payload without encryption.
17. *   **Web Shell Upload:** Attacker tries to upload a file with a server-side script extension (e.g., `.php`, `.aspx`, `.jsp`) disguised as an image, hoping to execute it for RCE. They might bypass filters by manipulating content-type, using double extensions (`shell.php.jpg`), or exploiting parsing discrepancies.
    *   **Exploiting Image Processing Libraries:** Uploading a maliciously crafted image file that triggers a vulnerability (e.g., buffer overflow, XXE) in the server-side library used to process or resize images.
18. a) **Repeater:** Allows an attacker to manually modify and resend individual HTTP requests multiple times to observe how the server responds to different inputs. Used for fine-grained testing of parameters.
    b) **Intruder:** Automates sending a large number of customized HTTP requests by iterating through payloads for specific positions in a request. Used for fuzzing, brute-forcing, and enumerating vulnerabilities like SQLi, XSS, IDORs, etc.
19. BOLA (Broken Object Level Authorization) occurs when an API endpoint allows a user to access or modify resources (objects) they shouldn't have permission for, typically by manipulating the ID of the resource in the API request.
    Example: A user `A` (ID: 101) makes a request to `/api/v1/users/101/profile`. If they can change the ID to `/api/v1/users/102/profile` and view/edit user `B`'s (ID: 102) profile without proper authorization checks, that's BOLA.
20. 1.  **Reconnaissance & Information Gathering:** Understand
